prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost (central) beam for this galaxy, closely corresponding to ~100 pc physical scale.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 50 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 5 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 1875 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 (to 20 km/s). The broad bandwidth will also allow a good determination of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free').

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost (central) beam for this galaxy, closely corresponding to ~100 pc physical scale.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 15 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 1.5 mJy in the central resolution element.
This can be attained in 10.9 mins of time on-source, if we use the 1875 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 (to 20 km/s). The broad bandwidth will also allow a good determination of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free').

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the central 1.4 arcsec (~100 pc) this galaxy, a small area about three times wider than the synthesized beam.
The total expected CO line flux in this system is 560 mJy, estimated from the measured PAH flux within the central 0.36 arcsec by Esquej et al. (2013). This region corresponds to our ALMA synthesized beam. Thus, we aim for a nominal 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 560 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 56 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 1875 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 (to 20 km/s). But given the brightness of this object, a much higher signal:noise is attainable in the nominal ~2 mins Science Goal exposure time, allowing us to search for other interesting characteristics (e.g. gas kinematical signatures).
The broad bandwidth will also allow a good determination of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free').

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the central beam for this galaxy.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 10 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 1 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is possible in 5.8 mins of time on-source, if we use the 2 GHz bandwidth setup.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the central beam for this galaxy.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 10 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 1 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is possible in 5.8 mins of time on-source, if we use the 2 GHz bandwidth setup.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the central beam for the galaxy.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 30 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 3 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2.6 mins of time on-source, if we use the 1875 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 (to 20 km/s). The broad bandwidth will also allow a good determination of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free').

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. This is our only target with some modest expected extension, with 100 pc corresponding to 6 arcsec in physical scale.
The peak flux from the total extended CO within the central ~few arcsec in this system is 1.9 Jy. However, most of this emission is likely concentrated in a well-known starburst ring which measures ~2.5 arcsec in size (cf. Chou et al. 2007 ApJ 670 116).
We take the most extreme (pessimistic) assumption that the flux is equally spread over a ~2.5 arcsec wide region, in which case it would be hardest to detect. This requires spreading the total flux over ~39 beams. We then aim for a nominal 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 49 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 5 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is possible in 2.7 mins of time on-source, if we use the 938 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 (to 10 km/s).
We note that, in contrast to our other targets, the 1875 MHz bandwidth setup cannot be used for this source because of its low redshift and the location of the representative frequency near the band edge. However, the choice of a slightly smaller bandwidth does not affect our primary goal of the CO measurement in any way, and will still allow an effective measurement of the continuum, given the expected line width.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost beam for the galaxy.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 50 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 5 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 1875 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16 (to 20 km/s). The broad bandwidth will also allow a good determination of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free').

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost beam for this galaxy.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 10 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 1 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is possible in 5.3 mins of time on-source, if we use the 2 GHz bandwidth setup.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost beam for this galaxy.
We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 10 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 1 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is possible in 5.5 mins of time on-source, if we use the 2 GHz bandwidth setup.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The presence of an apparent connection between star-formation and accretion activity is often cited in observational studies of AGN host galaxies, and is required by models of symbiotic black hole and galaxy growth. Yet, virtually all studies beyond the local universe probe vastly different physical scales when comparing the global (~kpc-scale) star-formation with nuclear accretion activity, meaning that any single gas reservoir cannot causally connect the two. What is required is a study of gas on fine scales where such a connection may be plausible. Here, we propose to map the distribution of the 12CO(1-0) transition in 10 actively-growing local Seyferts on scales of 0."4 (physical scales <100 pc) matched to our recent high angular resolution mid-infrared AGN imaging. We will search for signatures that distinguish those sources with ongoing circumnuclear star-formation, from those without. The cold gas distribution and mass probed by ALMA, together with our matched mid-infrared imaging and X-ray data will directly constrain any causal connection between the star-formation and accretion episodes in these objects via their reservoirs of cold nuclear gas.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Theoretical Physics and Astrophysics, Kiel University
Niels Bohr Institute, Copenhagen, University of
